p.seg: Zhòng Ní was staying in his home
and Zēngzǐ was in attendance.
The Master said:
"The Former Kings were in command of ultimate moral authority and also the crucial Way
and by these they instructed the people of the world.
The common people, as a result, lived in harmony.
superiors and subordinates were without resentment,
do you understand this well?"
Zēngzǐ stepped away from the mat and said:
"I, Shēn, am dull-witted,
how could I be qualified to understand that properly?"
The Master said:
"As for filial piety,
it is the basis of virtue,
it is that from which teaching arises.
Sit down again,
I will tell you about this."
"One's trunk and limbs, hair and skin,
one receives them from father and mother;
not to presume to destroy or injure them,
it is the beginning of filial piety.
To establish oneself as a person and practise the Way,
and spread one's fame to later generations,
to make thereby one's father and mother illustrious,
it is the last part of filial piety.
"Now as for filial piety,
it begins with serving one's parents,
it has its middle part in serving one's ruler,
and it has its final part in establishing one's person."
The Great Elegantiae say:
"Remember your ancestors,
cultivate your moral power."
The Master said:
"Those who take loving care for their parents dare not hate others,
those who show respect for their parents dare not be arrogant to others.
Completely realizing loving care and respect in service to parents
and applying moral integrity and filial piety to people,
serving as a good example for the world,
that is presumably the filial piety of the Son of Heaven.
Fǔxíng says:
'The ruler is good,
all the people rely on him."
They are not arrogant being in superior position,
and so they are not endangered although occupying high ranks.
They establish standards of modesty and pay close attention to the rules of conduct.
They are wealthy but not excessive.
To occupy high rank without being endangered,
that's how to keep high status for a long time.
To be wealthy but not excessive,
that's how to keep richness for a long time.
Only if richness and high status don't get seperated from themselves,
they will be able to safeguard their country,
and be in harmony with his people,
that's presumably the filial piety of feudal lords.
The Book of Songs says:
How careful were they!
as if approaching a deep abyss,
as if treading on thin ice.
If it is not the ritual garment of the Former Kings,
they dare not to dress it.
If they are not the exemplary words of the Former Kings,
they dare not to speak them up.
If it is not the virtuous behaviour of the Former Kings,
they dare not to carry it out.
Therefore if they don't speak about anything, that isn't in accordance with the moral standards
and don't carry out anything, that isn't in accordance with the Way,
then their mouth never needs to decide what to speak of,
and their body never needs to decide what to carry out.
their words fill the world but thera no mistakes caused by their mouth,
their actions fill the word but there is no resentment or hatred.
Only if these three things are accomplished,
then they are able to safeguard their temples of ancestors;
this is the filial piety of dignitaries.
The Book of Songs says:
He (Zhòng Shānfǔ) doesn't slacken, day or night,
thus he serves the ruler.
Learn to serve mother from serving father,
and then the loving care will be the same for both.
Learn to serve ruler from serving father,
and then the respect will be the same for both.
Therefore mother obtains one's loving care
and ruler obtains one's respect,
the one who has it both is father.
Therefore if one serves his ruler with filial piety, he's loyal,
if one serves his elders with respect, he's obedient,
if he's loyal, obedient, doesn't go astray
and by this he serves his superiors,
only then he can keep his rank
and safeguard the sacrifices,
that is presumably the filial piety of an official.
The Book of Songs says:
Stand up in the morning and go to sleep in the night,
don't humiliate your parents.
To deploy the Way of Heaven,
to distinguish vaious profits of Earth,
to be vigilant regarding oneself, to be economical with expenses,
to take good care of one's parents in that way,
this is the filial piety of common people.
Therefore as for everyone from the emperor down to the common people,
it never happened,
that filial piety was without the end and the beginning
but a serious trouble wouldn't come.
Zēngzǐ said:
How extreme is the greatness of filial piety!!!.
The Master said:
As for filial piety,
it is the guideline given by Heaven,
it is the moral principle given by Earth,
it is the proper conduct of common people.
It is the guideline of the world
and common people thus pattern on it.
They take the perspicacity of Heaven as a guideline,
rely on the benefits of Earth,
thus they act in accordance with the world.
By this, one's moral instruction isn't stern but it's brought to completion,
one's methods of government aren't harsh but they are carried out properly.
The Former Kings understood that training was able to educate the common people,
therefore they lead them by broad loving care
and none of the people would neglect his parents.
They showed virtue and righteousness to them
and the common people would begin to act properly.
They lead them by respect and polite deference
and the common people wouldn't be competitive.
They lead them by rituals and music
and the common people were in harmony.
They showed them what is nice and what ugly
and the common people understood properly the prohibitions.
The Book of Songs says:
"Illustrious are you, master Yǐn,
all the people look upwards to you in admiration."
The Master said:
In ancient times, as the enlightened kings governed the world by filial piety,
they dind't dare neglect servants of small states,
how much less the dukes, marquises, earls, viscounts and barons,
therefore they won the delight of ten thousand states.
By this, they served the Former Kings.
The one who governed a state well didn't dare treat widowers and widows with disrespect,
how much less the citizens,
therefore he won delight of the people;
thus he served the former rulers.
The one who took control of a family didn't dare overlook servants and concubines,
how much less his wife and children,
therefore he won delight of the people;
thus he served his parents.
Now it is so,
therefore when he lives, then the parents find comfort in him,
when he sacrifices, then the ghosts enjoy it.
Therefore the world is in harmony and peace,
no disasters occur,
disaster and chaos don't arise.
Therefore the way the enlightened kings ruled the world by filial piety was like this.
The Book of Songs says:
He has behaviour of great moral integrity,
all the states show harmonious subordination to him.
Zēngzǐ said:
Can I ask, whether the moral integrity of a sage
can't be something more than filial piety?
The Master said:
Among the natures between Heaven and Earth,
a human is the most noble one.
As far as the behaviour of people is concerned,
there is nothing greater than filial piety.
As far as filial piety is concerned, there is nothing greater than showing respect for father,
as far as showing respect for father is concerned, there is nothing greater than acting in accordance with Heaven;
Duke of Zhōu was surely such man.
In ancient times, Duke of Zhōu sacrificed to Hoù Jì in the suburbs,
thus he was in accordance with Heaven.
He did the ancestral sacrifice to king Wén in the Bright Hall,
thus he was in accordance with God.
Therefore all within the Four Seas,
everyone was coming to sacrifice according to his duty.
So, how could be the moral integrity of a sage something more than filial piety?
Therefore intimate relations arise in early age,
thus one gets every day more respectful in taking good care of his parents.
A sage gives instruction in respect relying on reverence,
gives instruction in loving care relying on loving care.
The moral instruction of a sage isn't stern but is brought to completion,
his methods of government aren't harsh but are carried out properly,
that which he relies on, is the basis (root).
The way? of the relation between a son and a father
is an inborn natural tendency,
it is the priciple of the relation between a ruler and a servant.
Parents give birth to one -
there is no greater (way of) continuation than it.
When the ruler deals with one like parents,
there no greater generosity than this.
Therefore not to take care of parents but take care of others,
it is called to be in contradiction with moral integrity.
Not to show respect to parents but show respect to others,
it is called to be in contradiction with rituals.
If he by these makes them obedient but himself is in opposition,
then common people won't have a model to follow.
They won't dwell on goodness,
but all will dwell on wicked morals.
A real gentleman doesn't appreciate it,
although he gets their (people's) support.
A real gentleman isn't like that;
while speaking, his thoughts can be told,
while putting in practice, his thoughts can be enjoyed,
his moral integrity and principles can be esteemed,
his way of doing official business can be made a model,
his appearance and comportment can be investigated,
his coming forward and withdrawal can be assesed,
thus he governs the people.
Thus because the people revere him and love him,
follow him like a guideline and imitate him.
Therefore he can accomplish proper moral training
and carry out proper administrative commands.
The Book of Songs says:
The gentleman is a person of excellent moral qualities,
has nothing wrong in his deportment.)
The Master said:
as for a filial son serving his parents,
when he's at home, he shows respect,
when he serves meal [to his parents], he shows delight,
when (his parents) are ill, he shows worry,
when he conducts mourning rites, he shows grief,
when he sacrifices [to them], he shows /reverence/
If these five (conditions) are provided,
only then he is able to serve his parents.
The one who serves his parents,
when he occupies a leader position, he's not arrogant,
when he's in a low position, he doesn't create political chaos,
when he is in an equal position, he doesn't engage in struggle,
If he occupies a leader position and is arrogant,
then he will be ruined.
If he is in a low position and creates political chaos,
then he will be punished.
If he's in an equal position and engages in struggle,
then he will be afflicted by weapons.
If these three things are not removed,
then even if he uses three kinds of domestic animals to care of (parents) every day
he is still to be counted as unfilial.
The Master said:
There are three thousand of the categories belonging to five punishments,
but there is no greater crime then unfiliality,
the one who makes demands on a ruler has no superiors,
the one who disapproves the sages has no model (to follow),
the one who opposes filial piety shows no loving care to parents,
this is the way of great chaos.
The Master said:
When instructing people in taking care of parents and love to them,
there is nothing better than filial piety.
When instructing people in rituals and obedience,
there is nothing better than fraternal love.
As for changing patterns of behaviour and customs,
there is nothing better than music.
As for keeping superiors secure and governing common people,
there is nothing better than rituals.
As for rituals,
it is only proper respect and that is all.
Therefore if a son shows respect for his father,
he feels pleased.
If a younger brother shows respect for the eldest brother,
he feels pleased.
If a minister shows respect for his ruler,
he feels pleased.
One shows respect for One man and thousands of ten thousand of people feel pleased.
Those for whom respect is shown are few and those who feel pleased are many,
this is called the crucial Way.
The Master said:
As for a gentleman teaching filial piety,
it is not that people? come and daily visit him.
To teach filial piety,
it is how to show respect for those of the world who are others'/people's fathers.
To teach fraternal love,
it is how to show respect for those of the world who are others'/people's eldest brothers.
To teach proper loyal service,
it is how to show respect for those of the world who are others'/people's rulers.
The Book of Songs says:
The happy and contented gentleman,
he's 'father and mother' of the people.
If not perfect moral integrity,
what else would be able to make people obedient gretaly like this.
The Master said:
a gentleman serves his parents with filial piety,
therefore loyalty can be moved on the ruler.
In serving his eldest brother he shows fraternal love,
therefore obedience can be moved on seniors.
His clan is in ordered in accordance with natural principles,
therefore order can be moved on officials.
Thus proper conduct is accomplished within his clan
and reputation is established for future generations.
Zēngzǐ said:
As far as loving care and respectul reverence,
comforting parents and spreading reputation are concerned,
I learnt about it.
I dare to ask, when a son follows his father's commands -
can it be called filial piety?
The Master said:
What words are this?!
What words are this?!
In ancient times, if the emperor had seven critical ministers,
although he had been wayward, he didn't loose the world.
If a feudal lord had five critical ministers,
although he had been wayward, he dind't loose his state.
If a dignitary had three critical ministers,
although he had been wayward, he didn't loose his clan.
If the official has critical friends,
he doesn't loose good reputation.
If a father has critical sons,
then he doesn't run into unrighteousness.
Therefore when (something's) wrong ,
then a son shouldn't be uncritical to his father,
a minister shouldn't be uncritical to his ruler.
Therefore if there is (something) wrong then he must criticize it.
To follow father's commands,
how could it be counted as filial piety?
The Master said:
In ancient times, the enlightened kings served fathers with filial piety,
therefore they dealed with Heaven with enlightenment ,
they served mother with filial piety,
therefore they dealed with Earth with intelectual sharpness.
The elders and the young were in accordance with proper order,
therefore the relationship between superiors and inferiors was well-ordered,
Heaven and Earth were clearly understood,
deities were clearly visible??
Even an emperor has certainly someone he respects,
that means he has a father. He has certainly someone he considers as the first,
that means he has elder brothers.
If he serves in the ancestral temple being extremely respectful,
he doesn't disregard his parents.
(If) He cultivates himself and acts carefully,
he's afraid to humiliate the ancestors.
If he serves in the ancestral temple being extremely respectful,
then the ghosts become illustrious.
The ultimate point of filial piety and fraternal love
gets to the gods,
shines within the Four Seas,
there is no place it doesn't get to.
The Book of Song says:
They came from the west and from the east,
from the south and from the north,
they never thought of not being obedient.
The Master said:
A gentleman serving his superiors,
when he comes forward, he yearns to exercise loyalty to the full,
when he moves back, he yearns to correct their faults,
he acts in accordance with their good points,
he corrects and helps them against their bad points,
therefore superiors and inferiors are on harmonious terms.
The Book of Songs says:
I love [them] in my heart,
why should I not say [it],
I keep them in the bottom of heart,
never forget them.
The Master said:
As for a filial son mourning for his parents,
his lamentation is without sobbing,
(his) ritual practice wú róng, ??
his speech isn't embellished,
when he wears a nice dress he feels uncomfortable,
when he hears music he isn't delighted,
when he eats exquisite food he doesn't appreciate it,
This is the real feeling of grief.
As for eating after three days,
he teaches people not to harm the living because of the dead,
that their maltreat would not destroy their life.
These are the methods of government of a sage.
His mourning period does not exceed three years, thus he shows to the people that there is an limit.
He makes coffins and burial garments for them [PARENTS] and puts them into the coffin,
lines up the ritual vessels and mourns for them.
He beats his breast, jumps, laments and weeps,
accompanies them (on their last way) with grief,
divines about their burial place
and buries them peacefully.
He builds an ancestral temple for them
and sacrifices to them in the way in which one sacrifices to ghosts.
He sacrifices to them in the course of seasons,
and lingers in thought on them at the appropriate time.
When they live, he's concerned with loving care and diligent respect,
when they are dead, he's concerned with mourning and grief,
so the basis of the people is completely realised,
the meaning of death and life is completely provided,
and the service of a filial son to his parents comes to a successful end.
